turn.1: What is the difference between a Delaunay triangulation and a greedy triangulation?
turn.2: Nevertheless, for randomly distributed point sets, both the Delaunay and greedy triangulations are within a logarithmic factor of the minimum weight.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The hardness result of Mulzer and Rote also implies the NP-hardness of finding an approximate solution with relative approximation error at most O(1/n).
turn.6: Thus, a fully polynomial approximation scheme for minimum weight triangulation is unlikely.
turn.7: What can you tell me about the hardness result?
turn.8: However, a quasi-polynomial approximation scheme is possible: for any constant ε > 0, a solution with approximation ratio 1 + ε can be found in quasi-polynomial time exp(O((log "n")).
turn.10: Because of the difficulty of finding the exact solutions of the minimum-weight triangulation, many authors have studied heuristics that may in some cases find the solution although they cannot be proven to work in all cases.
turn.12: In particular, much of this research has focused on the problem of finding sets of edges that are guaranteed to belong to the minimum-weight triangulation.
